newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korean banks' capital adequacy ratio edges lower.
newsitem.headline: S.Korean banks' capital adequacy ratio edges lower.

text.p: The capital adequacy ratio of South Korean banks under Bank for International Settlements (BIS) standards fell to an average of 9.14 percent at the end of last year from 9.33 percent a year earlier, the bank watchdog said on Tuesday.
The central Bank of Korea's Office of Bank Supervision said in a statement local banks' capital rose 14.1 percent last year, while risk-rated assets increased 16.4 percent.
It said the BIS capital adequacy ratio of eight banks, including Kookmin Bank and Korea Exchange Bank, gained, whereas that of 17 banks, including Chohung Bank and Shinhan Bank fell.
The BIS recommends a capital adequacy ratio of at least 8 percent.
The ratio indicates the overall quality of bank assets, a Seoul-based analyst said. If the ratio dropped below 8 percent banks would have to increase their capital, he said.
